verses.text: Saul spoke to Jonathan his son and to all his servants that they should kill David. But Jonathan, Saul’s son, delighted greatly in David.
verses.comment: The Hebrew 'delighted greatly in' is maintained over 'found favor in', matching previous usage in 18:1.

verses.text: Jonathan told David, saying, “Saul my father seeks to kill you. Therefore be on your guard in the morning; stay in a secret place and hide.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'be on your guard' preserves the Hebrew sense.

verses.text: I will go out and stand beside my father in the field where you are, and I will speak about you to my father. If I notice anything, I will tell you.”
verses.comment: Retains Hebrew structure; 'I notice anything' translates 'see what I see', meaning 'observe'.

verses.text: Jonathan spoke well of David to Saul his father and said to him, “Let not the king sin against his servant David, because he has not sinned against you and because his deeds have been very beneficial to you.
verses.comment: Translation keeps the phrase 'sin against', matching the Hebrew context.

verses.text: He risked his life and struck down the Philistine, and the LORD brought about a great salvation for all Israel. You saw it and rejoiced. Why then will you sin against innocent blood by killing David without cause?”
verses.comment: 'Risked his life' is literal Hebrew ('put his life in his hand'). 'Salvation' is kept as 'deliverance' would be equally appropriate.

verses.text: Saul listened to the voice of Jonathan and swore, “As the LORD lives, he shall not be put to death.”
verses.comment: 'As the LORD lives' is the standard divine oath form.

verses.text: So Jonathan called David, and Jonathan told him all these words. Jonathan brought David to Saul, and he was in his presence as before.
verses.comment: 'As before' translates Hebrew for 'as in previous times'.

verses.text: There was war again. David went out and fought with the Philistines and struck them with a great slaughter, so that they fled before him.
verses.comment: 'With a great slaughter' is a literal phrase.

verses.text: Then an evil spirit from the LORD came upon Saul as he sat in his house with his spear in his hand, while David was playing music.
verses.comment: 'Playing music' represents 'was playing with his hand'; i.e., playing the harp.

verses.text: Saul sought to pin David to the wall with the spear, but he slipped away from Saul’s presence, so Saul struck the spear into the wall. David fled and escaped that night.
verses.comment: 'Pin David to the wall' is a literal translation.

verses.text: Saul sent messengers to David’s house to watch him and to kill him in the morning. But Michal, David’s wife, told him, saying, “If you do not escape with your life tonight, tomorrow you will be killed.”
verses.comment: Direct representation of original wording.

verses.text: So Michal let David down through the window, and he went and fled and escaped.
verses.comment: 'Let David down through the window' echoes spies and Paul escaping.

verses.text: Michal took the household idol and laid it in the bed, and put a pillow of goat’s hair at its head, and covered it with a garment.
verses.comment: 'Household idol' translates 'teraphim'.

verses.text: When Saul sent messengers to take David, she said, “He is sick.”
verses.comment: Preserves original word order.

verses.text: Then Saul sent the messengers to see David, saying, “Bring him up to me in the bed, that I may kill him.”
verses.comment: Keeps literal emphasis of Saul's direct order.

verses.text: When the messengers came in, there was the household idol in the bed, with the pillow of goat’s hair at its head.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'there was' mirrors Hebrew construction.

verses.text: Saul said to Michal, “Why have you deceived me like this and sent my enemy away, so he has escaped?” Michal answered Saul, “He said to me, ‘Let me go! Why should I kill you?’”
verses.comment: 'Enemy' is literal. Michal's reply is verbatim in the original.

verses.text: Now David fled and escaped, and went to Samuel at Ramah, and told him all that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went and stayed at Naioth.
verses.comment: 'Stayed at' is literally 'dwelt at' in Hebrew.

verses.text: And it was told Saul, “David is at Naioth in Ramah.”
verses.comment: Direct translation; no significant divergence.

verses.text: Saul sent messengers to take David, and when they saw the company of prophets prophesying, and Samuel standing as appointed over them, the Spirit of God came upon the messengers of Saul, and they also prophesied.
verses.comment: 'Appointed' translates Hebrew 'standing as leader over them'.

verses.text: When it was told Saul, he sent other messengers, and they also prophesied. Then Saul sent messengers again a third time, and they also prophesied.
verses.comment: Literal repetition as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Then he also went to Ramah and came to the great well that is in Secu. And he asked, “Where are Samuel and David?” Someone said, “Behold, they are at Naioth in Ramah.”
verses.comment: 'Great well' and 'Secu' use Hebrew place names unchanged.

verses.text: So he went there to Naioth in Ramah. Then the Spirit of God came upon him as well, and as he went, he prophesied until he came to Naioth in Ramah.
verses.comment: 'Prophesied as he went' is literal and maintains the Hebrew sequence.

verses.text: He also stripped off his clothes and he too prophesied before Samuel, and lay down naked all that day and all that night. Therefore they say, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
verses.comment: 'Stripped off his clothes' is literal; 'naked' likely means underclothes/no outer garments. Phrase preserved as in the Hebrew.
